message: Happy New Year! Wishing you a blessed, healthy, and happy 2017!

This morning, I join my colleagues for the ceremonial swearing-in of the Congressional Black Caucus for the 115th Congress. It has been a distinct honor to have been selected by my colleagues to serve as the Chairman of the Caucus for the 114th Congress. I commend Congressman Cedric Richmond of Louisiana on becoming the incoming Chairman of the Caucus. We have much work to do in the coming years and I am confident that Congressman Richmond will be a strong leader on our priorities and interests.  Watch the swearing-in LIVE here: cbcfinc.org/live

Today, the House of Representatives held its first session of the 115th Congress. Thank you to the people of the great First District of North Carolina for the opportunity to serve you. I stand ready to fight for our needs and interests every step of the way.

To remain competitive in today's economy, we must invest in modern transportation infrastructure. I am proud of the strides being made in eastern NC to improve all modes of transportation.   http://www.rockymounttelegram.com/News/2017/01/03/Transportation-plans-move-forward.html
Temps are expected to fall below and remain below freezing this weekend. Be sure to protect your pipes. See the image for tips to get your home ready for the winter weather.

Proud to see Congressman Richard Hudson and my bipartisan bill to allow first responders to provide life-saving medications during emergencies unanimously pass the House today. This bill now heads to the U.S. Senate.  Read my full statement here: https://butterfield.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/butterfield-hudson-bipartisan-ems-bill-passes-house

I am proud to join Congressman David Price and Congresswoman Alma S. Adams in support of Governor Roy Cooper's plan to expand Medicaid. Republicans want to roll back coverage and make our families' health care a political football, but I stand ready to fight for access to care for more North Carolinians.

We need to be very honest with ourselves about what the war on the Affordable Care Act means for our communities. The reality is that — despite years of misdirection by Republicans — the ACA is making real, meaningful change for families across eastern North Carolina. Seniors know we have their backs. Young people are able to stay on their parents’ plans until they turn 26. And local hospitals are getting the support they need to serve our communities in the best way they know how. That’s something worth fighting for, that's why I say 'Thanks, Obama' — and that’s why I’m not backing down.
President Obama, what an honor it has been to work with you to move our country forward. Thank you for your leadership. I'm ready to keep fighting for the progress we've made. #TBT

Deadline Extended - Those impacted by Hurricane Matthew now have until January 23 to apply for assistance. This applies to homeowners, renters, and businesses.   Register by Jan. 23 with FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency online at DisasterAssistance.gov or call the FEMA Helpline at 800-621-3362.

The Republican plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act would attack the health security of families across NC. Proud to stand with NC's Congressman David Price and Congresswoman Alma S. Adams in the fight to protect our health care.  Join us in the fight to #KeepNCCovered. Here's how you can get involved:

Last night, I went on North Carolina's Capital Tonight to discuss the Republican effort to repeal the Affordable Care Act without offering a replacement and the need for Medicaid expansion in our state.   Watch last night's program in full here: http://www.twcnews.com/nc/triangle-sandhills/politics/2017/01/12/capital-tonight-jan--12--members-of-congress-on-aca--medicaid-expansion.html
Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s spirit and contributions live on every time we come together for a more fair and just world. Let us pause today to remember the life and work of Dr. King.
Today, Republicans took the first steps to repeal the Affordable Care Act but have still not offered an alternative plan, taking America's health coverage from care to chaos.

Hot off the press! Please read this week's newsletter to stay up to date with what's happening in Washington and to share how I can better serve you. To get my newsletters delivered directly to your email, visit my website to subscribe.

Last week, Congressional Republicans voted to begin the process of repealing the Affordable Care Act, despite not having a plan to replace the law. The American people deserve to know what Republicans' plan is before their health care and economic security are dismantled.  Hundreds of thousands of North Carolinians have gained coverage, and millions have had their coverage substantially improved. Here's how our families have benefitted from the ACA:  #KeepNCCovered
"I have decided to stick with love. Hate is too great a burden to bear." - Martin Luther King, Jr.
Great time honoring the life of Dr. Martin Luther King at Spring Street Baptist Church in Henderson.

This evening, I had the honor of swearing in my friend, Representative Larry D. Hall, as Secretary of the Department of Military and Veterans Affairs. I thank Larry for his leadership in the North Carolina House of Representatives. I know he will be a great asset to Governor Cooper's administration.

After prayerful consideration, I have made the decision to decline the invitation to attend the inaugural ceremony for the 45th President of the United States, President-Elect Donald J. Trump.  Donald Trump’s brand of division and insult, coupled with his lack of knowledge of the magnitude of the office he is about to enter, leads me to the conclusion that President-Elect Donald Trump is not prepared for the position of President and Commander-in-Chief.  In addition, I have grave concerns about the Russian hacking of our election process and the role, if any, Donald Trump played in this unlawful activity.  It is my hope that President Donald Trump will transform his behavior of insult and division, surround himself with knowledgeable thought leaders, and move our country in a positive direction.  He should resist any effort to eliminate health care for 30 million Americans and fundamentally change the Medicare and Medicaid programs that provide health care to our citizens.  I cannot in good conscience participate in this celebratory event.
This morning, I joined Judge Mike Morgan at Vance-Granville Community College to celebrate the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.  Thank you for having me!

TODAY is the deadline for those affected by Hurricane Matthew to register for disaster assistance from FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency.  To get started, visit http://www.fema.gov/disaster/4285 or call 800-621-3362.

President Trump’s plan to turn Medicaid into block grants is a radical change that will have far-reaching implications for our communities. During his campaign, Trump promised not to cut Medicaid, but that is exactly what block grants would do- they would penalize nearly 2 million North Carolinians who are currently enrolled in Medicaid and more than half a million additional North Carolinians who stand to gain access to Medicaid if our state expands the program.

President Trump’s executive orders to build a wall and increase enforcement actions are not a substitute for comprehensive immigration reform. Today’s actions will waste billions of taxpayer dollars and will perpetuate hate and fear. I will not support efforts that will terrorize our communities and tear families apart. We must build bridges, not walls.
Donald Trump's unsubstantiated claim that millions of people voted illegally is dangerous to our democracy. Where's the proof?

The Obama Administration gave us a Justice Department that aggressively worked to protect and expand civil rights for all Americans. With the nomination of Senator Jeff Sessions to Attorney General and the appointment of John Gore to lead the Civil Rights Division, President Trump further indicates the attack on civil rights and voting rights that is to come.

Today, I was proud to lend my support to Governor Cooper and NC Department of Transportation to name part of I-85 in Durham County in honor of the world renowned historian, Dr. John Hope Franklin. Dr. Franklin taught at Duke University  and North Carolina Central University . Colleagues considered him one of the most accomplished scholars in the world, and it is my hope that future generations will have the opportunity to learn Dr. Franklin's legacy. http://ow.ly/fnTr308ooQr
We are only 10 days into Donald Trump's presidency, but it is already clear that we must stand together to resist hateful and discriminatory actions from the Trump Administration.

Donald Trump should listen to the many voices of those speaking out across the country in outrage over his anti-Muslim, anti-refugee executive order. Tonight, I proudly stand with my colleagues and concerned Americans at the United States Supreme Court to demand Trump immediately rescind this hateful and divisive executive order.

This morning, the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee will vote on President Trump's pick for U.S. Attorney General, Senator Jeff Sessions.  It is important to recall Sen. Sessions' demonstrated ambivalence toward preserving and expanding the law to protect all Americans, including women, people of color, and the LGBT community.  I continue to stand against the confirmation of Senator Jeff Sessions to the position of Attorney General. https://butterfield.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/butterfield-trump-s-doj-picks-weaken-civil-rights-protection

Over the weekend, the President signed an executive order that targeted refugees and immigrants, causing chaos and concern across the nation as travelers, including Lawful Permanent Residents, children, and elderly persons were denied entry into the United States.    In response, I am proud to cosponsor the SOLVE, or Statue of Liberty Values Act to defund and rescind President Trump's executive order. This Act calls for Trump's order to have no effect or force of law. Today, I joined my colleagues on the House Floor to call for a unanimous vote on this legislation.

In the past week, many of you have contacted my office to express your grave concerns with President Trump's picks to lead the U.S. Department of Justice and the Department's Civil Rights Division.  Please know that I, too, am outraged by these selections. I hope you will continue to share your views with me, as well as your U.S. Senators, who will vote for or against the confirmation of Jeff Sessions to serve as our next Attorney General.

February marks Black History Month! This month, let us celebrate Black lives and leaders who are breaking down barriers every day.    I am thrilled that the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture  will celebrate its first Black History Month since its opening. The Museum tells the rich story of who we as a country are and reaffirms that Black history IS American history.  Starting TODAY at 9am: Free passes to the Museum for the month of May are available. To reserve up to 6 tickets, please visit: http://event.etix.com/ticket/e/1004039/timed-entry-pass-washington-national-museum-of-african-american-history-and-culture
My statement on President Trump's nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court:

Dr. John Hope Franklin was a world renowned historian and author who taught at North Carolina Central University and Duke University. His brilliance and passion for justice and truth continues to inspire so many. #BlackHistoryMonth

Dedicating Throwback Thursday to the “godmother of the civil rights movement,” Dr. Dorothy Height. Dorothy Height helped push civil rights and women’s rights into the national spotlight after World War II, standing as an equal among the likes of Martin Luther King, Jr., A. Phillip Randolph, Roy Wilkins, Whitney H. Young, and Floyd McKissick.  Dr. Height died in 2010 at the age of 98, but her legacy lives on.  I am thrilled that Dr. Height was commemorated this week by the U.S. Postal Service with the unveiling of the Dorothy Height Forever stamp. #TBT

I could not let the first week of Black History Month come to a close without honoring President Barack Obama, the 44th President of the United States and the first African American elected to the White House. President Obama had an inspiring message of hope that had a way of bringing people from all walks of life together. #BlackHistoryMonth
Rosa Parks would have been 104 years old today. Happy birthday to a fearless leader in the civil rights movement!

Truly honored to receive the Unsung Hero Award from the International Civil Rights Center & Museum in Greensboro on Saturday. From the court room to Congress, it has been my life's work to be a champion for protecting the civil and constitutional rights of all Americans.

This morning, I took a bus tour of the future GoTriangle light rail transit line in Durham and Orange County, along with Congressman David Price and North Carolina Central University Interim Chancellor Dr. Johnson Akinleye. This project will better support the Triangle’s rapid growth by offering transit alternatives for getting to work, to school, or to medical facilities in the area.

Repeal…wait a year…replace? Donald Trump and Republican leadership are trying to pull the wool over our eyes. More than 545,000 North Carolinians who have gained coverage through the Marketplace stand to lose health care coverage if the Affordable Care Act is dismantled. Instead of repealing the ACA, we should be building upon the incredible progress of the law to make it even more effective in improving the health outcomes of all Americans.

On the phone with fellow North Carolinians this morning sharing my strong opposition to the nomination of Betsy DeVos for education secretary. More than 50 million children attend public schools across the country. We must put public schools first. It is clear that Betsy DeVos has not done her homework in preparing for the job.
Today is National Black HIV/AIDS Awareness Day. Take a moment to get educated and share. #NBHAAD

Simply put- Betsy DeVos is not qualified to be Secretary of Education.  However, today the Senate voted 51-50 to confirm Ms. DeVos. Sadly, she will now lead the agency tasked with educating our children, standing up for public education, and supporting college students.

"There is no noise as powerful as the sound of the marching feet of a determined people.” - Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.  This Black History Month, I honor the contributions and progress made by African Americans. But there is work to be done. We are living in a time where a select few want to take our country backward. Now is the time to stay engaged. Don't give up. We need you on our journey toward true progress.
I was proud to partner with WE tv to remember leaders who give our children hope that if they work hard enough, they, too, can shatter glass ceilings. http://bit.ly/BHMpsa

The new CSX Carolina Connector is a great example of economic development opportunities in eastern North Carolina. This project will bring hundreds of direct jobs to the area and will make the region more competitive for industrial development. I look forward to great returns on this investment.

Last night, during debate on whether Jeff Sessions should be our next Attorney General, Senator Elizabeth Warren tried to read a letter written by Coretta Scott King. This letter, written 30 years ago, urged the Senate to reject the nomination of Jeff Sessions to a federal judgeship. In response, Senate Republicans silenced Senator Warren.  Read my thoughts in The Huffington Post on why silencing Coretta Scott King's words was the wrong move for Republicans.

The new President and Congress are now making decisions that will shape the direction of our country for many years to come.   So, as we move forward, I want to make sure to hear your thoughts and stay connected with you.   Please take my quick survey to share your thoughts with me → https://goo.gl/vWefhC

I was proud to work with Facebook to implement a new advertising policy that protects against discrimination by spelling out that advertisers on Facebook cannot discriminate against people based on “personal attributes such as race, ethnicity, color, national origin, religion, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, family status, disability, medical or genetic condition."

Under the Affordable Care Act, access to mental health and addiction treatment was expanded, "designating them as 'essential benefits' that must be covered."  Republican leadership's attempts to repeal the Affordable Care Act would have devastating impacts on mental health and addiction treatment.    We must protect our care.
This is unacceptable. What happened to the White House protecting sensitive information regarding foreign policy and national security? The American people deserve an answer as to why this happened.

Today, I joined my colleagues in demanding President Trump suspend National Security Advisor Michael Flynn and immediately deny him access to classified material until an investigation into his actions regarding Russia is complete.   After being exposed for misleading the Vice President and the Administration about his secret conversations with Russia's ambassador about U.S. sanctions against Russia, Michael Flynn has shown a shocking lack of judgment in putting America's national security first.

I'm excited to learn that the Durham County Democratic Executive Committee for District 29 today selected MaryAnn Black to serve out the remainder of former Rep. Larry Hall's term in the North Carolina House of Representatives. Governor Cooper is expected to appoint MaryAnn this week to the position.

I congratulate MaryAnn Black on her selection by the Durham County Democratic Party to fill the unexpired term for North Carolina House District 29. The seat was previously held by Secretary Larry D. Hall who now heads the North Carolina Department of Military and Veterans Affairs.

As quoted in today’s The Herald-Sun:  “Felipe de Jesus Molina Mendoza, the 2009 Riverside High School graduate seeking asylum, was released Tuesday after turning himself in to immigration officials in Charlotte.   “Molina Mendoza was scheduled to be deported to Mexico today, but his removal from the country was put on hold after U.S. Rep. G.K. Butterfield, D-N.C., asked U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officials to stay the order while Molina Mendoza appeals to the federal Appeals Court.”   I continue to monitor Felipe’s case closely.

With all that is going on in our state and across the country, it is time to come together to move our country forward in the face of attempts to take us back. Friends - I'm coming to the Triangle! My staff and I are getting ready for the Community Discussion on Saturday, February 25.   Let us know you're coming by registering here → http://butterfield.house.gov/about/events/forward-together-community-discussion

Any teacher will tell you we don’t learn anything by sitting back and merely hoping that a nugget of information will find its way to us. We have to work for it. There is absolutely no excuse for Republicans who are refusing to do their job by blocking an independent commission to get to the bottom of President Trump’s connections to Russia.
Spread the Word: My Washington, DC office is now accepting applications for a Digital/Press Intern to begin immediately. Deadline to apply is next Friday.
On April 23, 2015, Loretta Lynch, a North Carolina native, became the first African American woman to serve as our nation's top law enforcement officer. #BlackHistoryMonth

Recognize anyone in this picture? I arrived on the campus of North Carolina Central University as a freshman in the early 1960's. Back then, NCCU was North Carolina College at Durham. I have many great memories of my time at NCCU. HBCUs have long played an important role in enabling students of color to achieve the American dream. This #blackhistorymonth, I honor them. #flashbackfriday

Make no mistake- since its enactment in 2010, the Affordable Care Act (ACA) has supported the American people on cost, quality, and coverage of health care.  With Republicans taking steps to roll back the progress made under the ACA, I will continue to fight to ensure that every American has access to affordable, quality health coverage.  Read a quick and simple overview of how the ACA has supported our health and economic security: https://goo.gl/bEF87U

The American people want Congress focused on raising wages and creating good-paying jobs for everyone, everywhere in America.  Instead, House Republican leaders say that they are moving forward with efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act. Yet, after seven years, Republicans still do not have a plan to replace the ACA.  35,924 in North Carolina's First District gained health care in the 3 years after the ACA went into effect and 511,000 North Carolinians total have gained coverage since the ACA was implemented. I refuse to take that care away from them.
It was a true honor to be recognized for my work in the African American community during the Black History Month service at Sycamore Hill Missionary Baptist Church in Greenville on Saturday.

Since the start of the new Congress, I have been energized by the groundswell of interest from so many North Carolinians -people of all ages and backgrounds-  who have been in touch with me and my office asking how we can protect the progress we've made in our country and continue to move forward. We have a lot of challenges ahead, but now is the time to roll up our sleeves and raise our voices on the issues that matter most to us.  Please join me this Saturday for a community discussion on how we can resist efforts to take our country backward.  Share this video and let folks know to join us this Saturday.  For more info & to RSVP: http://butterfield.house.gov/about/events/forward-together-community-discussion

Yesterday, I attended the opening of the Metropolitan Community Health Service's new on-site pharmacy in Williamston. I was glad to join Mayor Joyce Whichard-Brown for the renaming of the community room in her honor. A well deserved recognition!

Happy birthday to my friend and civil rights hero, Congressman John Lewis. Thank you for always reminding us what #goodtrouble looks like.  Pictured here with former Congresswoman Eva M. Clayton and the late Congressman Lucien E. Blackwell.
Congressman Butterfield in Durham, NC for a community discussion.

It was an honor to speak at the Black History Month celebration at Jackson Chapel First Missionary Baptist Church in Wilson on Friday. Black History Month reminds our nation of where we’ve been and helps to focus us on where we’re headed in the future.

On Saturday, I spoke to more than 600 constituents at my first community discussion of 2017. Topics discussed included updates on the first 30 days of the Trump Administration, the fight to protect the Affordable Care Act, and concerns surrounding immigration and civil liberties.   I thank all who attended and raised questions. I look forward to hosting more community discussions in the First District in coming weeks.  I continue to urge residents to stay engaged in the political process and I proudly re-affirm my commitment to speaking on your behalf in Washington.  Read more on my thoughts following Saturday's community discussion and view photos from the event:

As predicted, the attack on voting rights has begun under Attorney General Jeff Sessions’ leadership at the U.S. Department of Justice. The Trump Administration, with AG Sessions in the lead, has decided not to defend the voting rights of minorities and the poor in Texas. This is a shameful decision by the Trump Administration and Attorney General Sessions.

It is with a heavy heart today that we mourn the passing of the legendary Bill Ellis. Bill led a remarkable life, founding the popular Bill Ellis Barbecue in Wilson in 1963. My thoughts and prayers are with him and his entire family.

Today is Rare Disease Day 2017! Too many families are affected by rare diseases and are unable to get care because of the lack of adequate treatment. The good news is that the advancements in research and awareness of the rare disease community is providing new hope for people living with a rare disease. Congress must invest in research to ensure that we continue to make progress in combating these dangerous diseases. As Co-Chair of the Rare Disease Congressional Caucus, I am proud of the advancements being made to increase the number of safe, effective, and affordable treatments that are available for people with rare diseases.  Help raise awareness and be part of the change by learning more about Rare Disease Day and sharing information with your network.

Enjoyed meeting with the Durham County Board of Commissioners today in my Washington, DC office. We had a productive discussion on transit, housing, and other issues of importance in the First District.   Durham County Government

Yesterday, I proudly reintroduced the RACE for Children Act (Research to Accelerate Cures and Equity for Children Act) along with U.S. Senators Michael Bennet, Marco Rubio, Chris Van Hollen, and Cory Gardner, and U.S. Representatives Michael T. McCaul, Sean Duffy, and Yvette Clarke.   A harsh reality for children with cancer is that there are still limited pediatric studies for cancer drugs for children. This bill aims to change that by updating the law to give children with cancer access to clinical trials of the most promising cancer drugs.

HBCUs like North Carolina Central University are essential to provide educational opportunities to young people and preparing our workforce for the future. Since Jimmy Carter, Presidents have signed Executive Orders that recognize the importance of HBCUs to communities across the country. The Administration’s Executive Order issued this afternoon honors that tradition, but much more support is needed to make a difference at HBCUs and in the lives of young people across the country. It is absolutely essential that we increase federal investment in HBCUs.
My response to President Trump’s first address to a Joint Session of Congress:

Today marks the first day of Women's History Month. From fighting for freedom from slavery, women's rights, and fairness in the workplace and education, hundreds of women have paved the way for future generations. This month, let us honor the many women who have helped shape the world.

Last Saturday, I spoke with more than 600 constituents at my community discussion in Durham. Thank you to all who attended and to the local leaders who shared information on getting engaged. I will be holding more community discussions in our region in the coming weeks so I can hear your thoughts on how we can continue moving forward together.
Thank you to Secretary Trogdon and North Carolina Department of Transportation for stopping by my Washington, DC office today to discuss plans to improve transportation in North Carolina.

Yesterday evening, it was reported that then-Senator Jeff Sessions, a long-serving Donald Trump campaign advisor, spoke with Russia’s ambassador to the United States last year, contrary to testimony he provided under oath to the Senate Judiciary Committee during his confirmation hearings about meetings with Russian officials.  Jeff Sessions has once again shown he is not fit to serve as our nation’s top law enforcement officer.  It is essential that there be trust between the U.S. Attorney General and the American people.  By testifying under oath that he did not have communications with the Russians during his Senate confirmation hearing, Jeff Sessions has breached this trust and raises questions of apparent perjury that must be investigated.  In light of this report and last month’s call for Michael Flynn’s resignation after he concealed conversations with the Russians, there is no question that we need an independent, bipartisan, transparent commission to investigate this Administration’s connections and communications with Russia.  At minimum, the Attorney General must recuse himself from any oversight of an investigation of senior Trump officials’ ties to the Russian government.

More than half a million North Carolinians have gained coverage since the Affordable Care Act was implemented and thousands more have had their coverage substantially improved. Access to basic health coverage is a right that all North Carolinians and Americans deserve and I stand ready to protect the Affordable Care Act and Medicaid from Republican efforts to derail the healthcare progress we have made.

It appears that House Republicans are planning to hold a markup of their legislation to repeal the Affordable Care Act next week, but they are refusing to allow Democrats to read the bill.  They have hidden the bill in a room in the United States Capitol and are only allowing certain Republican members of Congress access to it.  This isn’t democracy – it’s a direct reversal of the promise Republicans made to the American people to run an open and transparent government.    I am deeply concerned that Republicans are allowing this bill that is being kept secret from Democratic members of Congress and the American people to advance through the legislative process without any congressional hearings or public input.  This Republican stonewalling is nothing more than a sneak attack to take away health care from millions of Americans.  The American people deserve to know the details of any health care plan being proposed and should  be afforded the the opportunity to make their views known to their elected representatives.    Yesterday I was joined by my Democratic colleagues on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, in sending a letter to Chairman Greg Walden (R-OR) to demand that the text of the ACA repeal bill be posted for the public to view for at least 30 days before a markup is held.  It’s sad and disappointing, but unfortunately not at all surprising, that Republican members of Congress are hiding such a consequential bill from their colleagues and the American people.  Our country deserves better than this manufactured sideshow.

Congratulations to Robert Evans, District Attorney for the Seventh Judicial District, on his appointment to serve as chairman of Governor Roy Cooper’s newly formed Crime Commission.  Governor Cooper’s new Crime Commission will play a critical role in advising the Governor on crime and justice issues in our state. District Attorney Evans understands the justice and law enforcement system well, especially as it relates to meeting the needs of our state. His extensive experience as district attorney for Nash, Edgecombe, and Wilson Counties, as a prior District Court Judge, and as a general practice attorney makes him a great choice to advocate for our state. I look forward to working with Robert in his new role.  Robert Evans will lead 44 members of the Crime Commission as the chief advisory body to the Governor and the Secretary of the Department of Public Safety on crime and justice issues. The Commission will also set program priorities and review and make recommendations to the Governor for grant awards.
I am saddened to learn of the passing of former Durham County Manager George H. Williams. I extend my thoughts and prayers to his family and all that were impacted by his work during this time.
Veteran and 2016 East Carolina University grad, Zack Cleghorn has an inspiring story of overcoming hardship.

Hot off the press! This week in Washington was a busy one. Read this week's newsletter to get a run down. Get my weekly newsletter delivered directly to your email by visiting my website Butterfield.House.gov

Following a series of defeats in court for his first travel ban, President Trump just signed another executive order based in fear and division.  This revised executive order is nothing more than a repackaging of the first travel ban. It still bans immigrants only from Muslim-majority countries. It does nothing to change the unconstitutional and discriminatory intent of the ban. And it is still un-American. The President claims he is acting to make America safer, but the actions taken by his Administration are harmful to our national security. We will not stand for this kind of discrimination.
My thoughts on the Republican plan to replace the Affordable Care Act? It will cost Americans more money while providing fewer protections- and will lead to millions losing healthcare altogether.
Just gave my opening statement to protect the progress made under the ACA. I will be posting updates today as we go through the markup process.

In Republicans’ haste to piece together their replacement plan for the Affordable Care Act, they have forgotten the millions of Americans who will suffer from higher costs, fewer benefits and protections- and those who will lose healthcare altogether under their replacement. I plan to do everything in my power to remind them of these enormous consequences.   Republicans in Congress had 7 years to prep this plan and it is completely inadequate.
Wishing Pirate Nation a happy 110th birthday! Today, we celebrate and applaud East Carolina University's innovation and rich legacy in North Carolina and across the nation.

We are at hour 24 of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce markup of the Republican's bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act. The replacement bill changes Medicaid into a per capita cap funding structure that will inevitably result in the rationing of care; eliminates Medicaid expansion that has helped millions of Americans to gain affordable healthcare coverage; and removes the mandate that Medicaid cover all Essential Health Benefits.  I will not support a plan to pay more for less coverage and gut Medicaid and Medicare. This is unacceptable.

I was in the House Energy and Commerce Committee's full committee markup for over 27 hours. We have not slept and I remain in the fight to shed light on the dangerous consequences of the Republican plan to repeal the ACA.
After 27+ hours of debate, it is clear the Affordable Care Act repeal bill means less coverage, fewer protections and higher costs for seniors & working families.

This week, I had the opportunity to commemorate Women’s History Month with a discussion with Dr. Carla Hayden, the 14th Librarian of Congress.   Even though more than eighty percent of American librarians are women, the position of Librarian of Congress has been held exclusively by white men for over 200 years.  Dr. Hayden is the first woman and the first African American to hold the position.  Hear about the women who inspire us and Dr. Hayden’s recommendations for North Carolinians visiting The Library of Congress for the first time here: http://butterfield.house.gov/media-center/videos

These days, families are having to work harder and harder to make ends meet, put their children through school, and save for a secure retirement. We need a plan that creates more high-paying jobs and provides support for more Americans to get ahead. My Jobs and Justice agenda calls for a recommitment to leveling the playing field for all.   Learn more about how I'm fighting for #JobsandJustice for North Carolinians and people across the country: http://butterfield.house.gov/priorities/jobs-and-justice

Important reminder during tax season: Take advantage of the tax credits you’re eligible for!  A number of federal tax credits exist to help taxpayers keep more of their earnings.  One of the most substantial credits is the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC).  Find out if you qualify for EITC and take full advantage of your tax situation this year: http://butterfield.house.gov/priorities/jobs-justice/understanding-tax-credits
I was glad to welcome cotton farmers from eastern NC to my Washington office last week. I'm proud to support the cotton production and ginning industries in the Southeast.
We had an engaging conversation and Q&A this morning with residents in Greenville during the Pitt County Council on Aging legislative meeting. Thank you to all who attended!

The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office report is in and it's worse than expected. The Republican plan to replace the Affordable Care Act will cause 24 million Americans to lose health coverage by 2026.  Despite growing fears that their plan is inadequate, Congressional Republicans are rushing to rip away healthcare from millions including families, older Americans, and Americans with disabilities. This will have real life consequences for Americans.

Mrs. Sallie B. Howard has made an immeasurable contribution to the arts and education across the country. I am proud to honor my friend and legendary citizen of Wilson, NC this Women's History Month!  #WomensHistoryMonth  Sallie B. Howard School for the Arts and Education

Throughout his campaign for president, Donald Trump claimed he alone would be a true defender of programs like Medicare and Medicaid. But it looks like he spoke too soon. If Congress adopts President Trump’s proposed budget, agencies such as the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Institutes of Health, and the State Department face large cuts. Smaller agencies such as the National Endowment for the Arts and the Corporation for Public Broadcasting stand to be eliminated under President Trump’s plan. The President’s proposal also calls for the elimination of key economic development agencies including the Minority Business Development Agency and the Economic Development Administration.  This budget fails to address our economic problems by slashing funding that supports our long-standing commitment to increase economic opportunities through investments in education, infrastructure, affordable housing, and job training. Many of these programs sustain older Americans and so many in eastern North Carolina.  I am outraged by the President’s call to drastically cut funding for the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). This will be devastating to programs that support public housing in low-income communities and, quite frankly, keep a roof over people’s heads. Under the President’s proposal, the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) and the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) will be cut entirely, significantly impacting small, rural communities like the ones in my congressional district. More than 88,000 households in North Carolina benefit from LIHEAP, and the very threat of this program’s elimination could push these families beyond the tipping point. The CDBG program has been a successful means of helping communities secure federal funding for local neighborhood revitalization, housing rehabilitation, and economic development activities.  I cannot and will not support measures that take a wrecking ball to programs that have long supported low and moderate-income Americans.  President Trump calls his proposal the ‘America First’ budget, but this plan puts many Americans last.

Don’t be fooled. The Republican health care plan could hurt you- even if you get insurance through your employer.  Under the Affordable Care Act, health care plans could not impose annual or lifetime limits on reimbursements for expenses incurred from 10 essential benefits such as emergency services, rehabilitative services, inpatient care, outpatient care, maternity and newborn care, mental health and addiction treatment, lab tests, preventive care, prescriptions, and pediatric services, including oral and vision care.   The GOP plan would eliminate this mandate, allowing states to waive requirements for insurance companies. This could force millions of people with pre-existing conditions to face higher out-of-pocket costs and struggle to find affordable plans that cover the services and treatments they need.

The Republican healthcare bill threatens many health care choices for North Carolinians- especially families in rural areas- primarily because of the dismantling of Medicaid and elimination of many of the protections provided under the Affordable Care Act.  Last year under the Affordable Care Act, Medicaid offered health coverage to over 1 million rural North Carolinians and has become a critical financial lifeline for rural hospitals. Sadly, the Republican bill would significantly cut the Medicaid program as we know it. Additionally, families in rural areas have greatly benefitted from the ACA’s premium tax credits and cost-sharing protections.  These benefits stand to be eliminated under the GOP healthcare bill, leaving many rural Americans unable to afford their high insurance premiums. The Republican plan would also eliminate protections that enable people with pre-existing conditions to get the same coverage and services as healthy people, forcing many rural and older Americans to pay much higher out-of-pocket costs.   With the Senate expected to vote on this bill next week, we must continue to fight this harmful legislation every step of the way.

The news that President Trump plans to terminate the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which provides certainty to young men and women who were brought to America as children, is deeply concerning. This is purely a political move by the president, who, in the past, promised to treat these young people with compassion. Now, he is threatening the futures of nearly 800,000 young people who risk being subjected to deportation. Since its creation, DACA has allowed young people to receive temporary and renewable work permits, allowing them to serve as nurses, educators, engineers, and leaders in our communities. They contribute to our communities and provide a positive economic impact in our state. The president should think twice before betraying these young people who have passed background checks and were granted permission to live and work legally in America. In fact, he should be embracing their stories and contributions.

Happy birthday to the late Julius Chambers. Julius Chambers was a civil rights icon in North Carolina and across the country. I first heard the name “Julius Chambers” in 1965, on my first day of history class at North Carolina Central University. The professor looked at me and said, “Mr. Butterfield, you are sitting in the seat that Julius Chambers once sat!” I didn’t know the significance of this statement until I met Julius, became his friend, and started following his career. Julius was a founding member of Ferguson, Stein & Chambers, the first integrated law firm in North Carolina. In courtrooms across America, Julius Chambers and his legal team litigated hundreds of cases to guarantee opportunity for African American citizens. In 1993, Julius became Chancellor at North Carolina Central University, his college alma mater. I am grateful to have known this giant of a man, and I am glad his legacy lives on in the lives of hundreds of young people who continue to fight the good fight.

This week during the House Energy and Commerce Committee markup, I offered my amendment to extend the National Health Service Corps (NHSC) program. The NHSC is a national program that provides loan repayment and scholarship awards to primary care, mental health, and dental health professionals in exchange for practicing in federally designated Health Professional Shortage Areas (HPSA). My amendment would reauthorize the National Health Service Corps for five years and increase funding for the program.  Seventy-five percent of the fourteen counties in the First Congressional District are federally-designated Health Professional Shortage Areas. That is why a strengthened National Health Service Corps is critical for our community. It is important that residents, particularly those in rural areas, have access to care, and my amendment takes an important step forward by continuing the NHSC program with the appropriate funding levels. Today, House Republicans voted in favor of a tax hike for 36 million middle class households, adding $1.5 trillion to the deficit, and robbing $1.5 trillion from Medicare and Medicaid.  The Republican tax plan that passed the House today eliminates personal deductions for medical expenses creating further hardship for people facing chronic illness; eliminates deductions for state and local income taxes resulting in higher taxes for people who cannot afford it; and eliminates deductions for interest paid on student loans making a quality education less accessible.  Tax reform should be bipartisan and provide protections for critical programs that working families and small businesses rely on, while ensuring that our country’s top earners and corporations pay their fair share of taxes.  That’s what the American people deserve.  I remain ready and willing to work across party lines to achieve responsible tax reform.  I urge the United States Senate to reject the House bill and work to achieve real results for the American people.

On World AIDS Day, I celebrate the progress we’ve made over the last few decades in halting the AIDS epidemic. Thanks to the work of bipartisan initiatives like the Global Fund, PEPFAR, Ryan White, and the Minority AIDS Initiative, we are closer than ever to ending AIDS by 2030 both in the U.S. and abroad. However, much work lies ahead. Across the world, 36.7 million people are still living with the virus – and too many of them are locked out of the education, treatment & care that they need. Today, let’s recommit to ending AIDS & empowering the millions of people impacted by the epidemic around the world.
